#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Grandfather held in Guantanamo dies of cancer
#Text=Monday , December 31 , 2007
#Text=Joint Task Force Guantanamo ( JTF-GTMO ) reported a fifth Guantanamo captive , named Abdul Razzak , died in captivity , on December 30 , 2007 .
#Text=JTF-GTMO asserted that Razzak had complained of abdominal pains in September 2007 , and had begun to receive cancer therapy in late October 2007 .
#Text=JTF-GTMO estimated that he was born in 1939 .
#Text=According to the JTF-GTMO press release that announced his death :
#Text=Abdul Razzak was assessed to be an experienced jihadist with command responsibilities and was assessed to have had multiple links to anti-coalition forces .
#Text=He was detained in Guantanamo as an enemy combatant , consistent with the international law of Armed Conflict .
#Text=Abdul Razzak was one of the few Guantanamo captives who continued to attend his Combatant Status Review Tribunal and his annual Annual Review Board hearings .

#Text=Abdul Razzak had disputed all but one of the allegations against him , at each opportunity , and had provided his JTF-GTMO interrogators and the officers who sat on his CSR Tribunal and ARB hearing with easily verifiable corroborated details .
#Text=At each of his Administrative review the officers were unaware of the exculpatory details he had provided .

#Text=The one allegation that Abdul Razzak acknowledged was that he had been subjected to involuntary conscription , and had served the Taliban for three months out of every year for the five years they were in power before he fled Afghanistan .
#Text=He had , however , not served in the Taliban 's armed forces , but had been a truck driver , delivering non-military supplies .
#Text=One of the main allegations against Abdul Razzak was that he had plotted to help free Taliban leaders .

#Text=Abdul Razzak testified that , on the contrary , two years prior to al Qaeda 's attacks on September 11th , 2001 , he and his son had played a key role in a successful plot to free three imprisoned senior Northern Alliance leaders , who he identified as " Ismail Khan , Haji Zahir , son of vice president Haji Qadir and General Qassim . " -- Ismail Khan is currently the Minister of Energy .
#Text=Abdul Razzak testified that his son , one of the relatively few Afghans who was fluent in English , had been conscripted by the Taliban , so he could provide some computer support .
#Text=His son had contacted anti-Taliban forces , secured funds to purchase a four-wheel drive vehicle .
#Text=His son , using the trust the Taliban had placed in him , due to his computer support , had lead the three men out of their imprisonment .
#Text=Abdul Razzak had driven the four by four .
#Text=The vehicle was damaged by a land mine .
#Text=Abdul Razzak 's hand was injured .
#Text=His son lost a foot .
#Text=But the Northern Alliance leaders were rescued .
#Text=Abdul Razzak testified that when they arrived in Iran the Afghanistan Council paid his living expenses .
#Text=But , when Hamid Karzai assumed power , following the ouster of the Taliban , he was told that the pension would be discontinued , because Afghanistan now had a democratic government .
#Text=Abdul Razzak testified that he then returned to Afghanistan , where he was falsely denounced by a distant cousin named Mohammed Jan .
#Text=Mohammed Jan 's branch of the family was engaged in a feud with his branch , that had lead to the death of his father , two uncles , and three of his sons .

#Text=Abdul Razzak was also accused of being a leader of anti-coalition forces , and of being a member of the Hezb-e-Islami Gulbuddin , an older militia , which was first founded to oppose the regime of Mohammed Daoud Khan , the politician who had ousted Mohammed Zahir Shah , the last King of Afghanistan , in 1973 .
#Text=In 1979 this militia split , and has been lead , since then , by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar .
#Text=Gulbuddin Hekmatyar 's militia played a major role in the resistance to the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan .
#Text=This militia acquired a reputation for ruthlessness , and disregard for civilian life .
#Text=Abdul Razzak testified that his only contact with the Hezb-e-Islami Gulbuddin militia was early in the war against the Soviets .
#Text=He testified he was imprisoned for four and a half months in an underground pit .
#Text=They had captured him because he had served as a driver for a member of the communist regime .
#Text=American intelligence analysts assert that , when Osama bin Laden was leaving Sudan , Gulbuddin Hekmatyar offered him sanctuary in the areas of Afghanistan under his control .
#Text=Although not part of the Northern Alliance the Hezb-e-Islami Gulbuddin militia fought with the Taliban , prior to their ouster .
#Text=When the USA allied with the Northern Alliance and other resistance forces to oust the Taliban
#Text=the Hezb-e-Islami Gulbuddin militia fought against the USA .
#Text=In 2003 the Hezb-e-Islami Gulbuddin formed an alliance with the rump of the Taliban .

#Text=Abdul Razzak was also accused of being the Abdul Razak who had been the second in command of the Taliban 's 40-man unit , even though witnesses described Abdul Razak the commander as a much younger man , with a full black beard .
#Text=Americans held five other men in Guantanamo named Abdul Razak .
